Understanding Electrical Measurements ⚡ Electricity itself is invisible — we cannot see voltage, current, or resistance directly.
Yet through measurement, we give shape to this invisible force, turning it into something we can control, predict, and harness.
Electrical measurements are, quite literally, the language of circuits.
They tell us what a system is doing, how it behaves under load, and whether it’s alive or silent.
Why Electrical Measurement Matters Every electrical or electronic project — from the simplest LED circuit to advanced biomedical instruments — depends on accurate measurement.
Measurement allows us to:
Diagnose faults Validate designs Calibrate instruments Understand physical behavior (like voltage drops, power loss, or signal distortion) Without measurement, engineering would be little more than guessing.
The Three Fundamental Quantities At the heart of all electrical measurement lie three primary quantities:
⚡ Voltage (V) The potential difference between two points — the electrical “pressure” that pushes charges through a circuit.
Measured in volts (V) using a voltmeter or the voltage mode of a multimeter.
Think of voltage as the “push” that drives electrons.
🔄 Current (I) The flow of electric charge through a conductor — measured in amperes (A).
Current tells us how much charge moves per second.
Measured with an ammeter, or indirectly using a shunt resistor and voltage drop.
Current is like the amount of water flowing through a pipe per second.
🧱 Resistance (R) The opposition offered by material to current flow — measured in ohms (Ω).
Every conductor, even a wire, resists current slightly.
Measured using an ohmmeter or the resistance mode of a multimeter.
Resistance determines how easily electricity can move through a path.
Instruments of Measurement Modern engineers rely on several key instruments:
Instrument Measures Typical Range Notes Multimeter Voltage, Current, Resistance Varies Essential all-in-one tool Oscilloscope Time-varying Voltage mV to hundreds of V Visualizes waveforms Wattmeter Power Watts (W) Useful in AC systems LCR Meter Inductance, Capacitance, Resistance µH, µF, Ω For component characterization Function Generator (Not measurement, but signal source) Hz–MHz Used to test responses Measurement in the Real World In practical circuits, measurement technique matters as much as the instrument.
Always measure voltage in parallel, current in series. Consider the instrument’s internal resistance — it can affect readings. Use differential probes for high-voltage or floating measurements. In high-precision systems, calibration and shielding are crucial. The Beauty of Measurement Electrical measurement isn’t just technical — it’s poetic in a way.
You’re quantifying something that cannot be seen, only felt through instruments.
Each reading tells a story — of motion, resistance, balance, and transformation.
“To measure is to know. If you cannot measure it, you cannot improve it.”
— Lord Kelvin
Looking Ahead 🔭 In upcoming articles, I’ll explore:
The theory and use of bridges (Wheatstone, Kelvin, Maxwell) Error and uncertainty analysis in instrumentation How to design and calibrate measurement systems for embedded and biomedical applications Stay tuned — because the journey from volts and amps to insight and control is just beginnin
title: Understanding Electrical Measurements — The Language of Circuits

The Frugality of Life 🌿 We live in a world that constantly whispers, “More.”
More things. More success. More validation.
But what if the secret to a fulfilling life lies not in adding, but in subtracting?
Frugality isn’t about deprivation. It’s about deliberation — choosing consciously where our time, energy, and money flow. It’s about aligning our lives with what actually brings peace and purpose, rather than chasing what sparkles for a moment and fades the next.
The Essence of Frugality Frugality begins with gratitude.
When we recognize what we already have — the warmth of morning light, a calm cup of tea, a kind word — we stop searching frantically for more.
We start to see abundance in simplicity.
Living frugally teaches us that:
Every possession has a hidden cost — of space, attention, and care. Every purchase is a vote for the kind of world we want to build. Every act of restraint sharpens appreciation for what remains. Beyond Money To be frugal in life is not just to spend less — it’s to waste less:
Less time in distraction. Less energy on resentment. Less emotion on things outside our control. It’s an act of quiet rebellion against the chaos of consumption.
A way to reclaim sovereignty over our own minds.
The Joy of Enough There’s a quiet joy in realizing that enough is a moving boundary we can choose to stop chasing.
Enough clothes.
Enough gadgets.
Enough goals.
When “enough” settles in the heart, contentment follows naturally.
Closing Thoughts 🌸 Frugality isn’t an aesthetic — it’s a mindset.
It’s not about living less, but about living lightly, with clarity and purpose.
“The cost of a thing is the amount of what I will call life which is required to be exchanged for it.”
— Henry David Thoreau
Here’s to a life not cluttered by possessions, but enriched by perspective.
– Souren
title: The Frugality of Life — Finding Grace in Simplicity

Welcome to My Blog 🌱 Hey there — and welcome!
This is the very first post on my Hugo-powered blog, and I couldn’t be more excited to finally hit publish.
I’ve been meaning to start this space for a while — a place where I can write, explore ideas, and share what I’m learning along the way. Whether it’s about technology, engineering, personal projects, or just random reflections, this blog is going to be my digital notebook — open to anyone curious enough to read.
Why I Started This Blog There’s something powerful about putting thoughts into words. Writing forces clarity, and clarity builds growth.
I wanted a clean, fast, and minimal platform — so Hugo felt like the perfect fit. It’s lightweight, Markdown-based, and gives me full control over how my content looks and behaves.
What You Can Expect Here Over time, I plan to post about:
💻 Tech experiments & coding projects ⚙️ Engineering, electronics, and system design 📚 Notes from books, ideas, and experiences 💡 Occasional deep dives into things I find fascinating This blog isn’t about perfection — it’s about progress and sharing.
A Note on Simplicity In a world full of noisy feeds and endless scrolling, I want this site to feel different —
a quiet, thoughtful space to pause, learn, and build together.
If you’re reading this, you’re already part of that journey. So, thank you.
Until Next Time 👋 I’ll be posting regularly, so stay tuned for updates.
If you’d like to connect or share ideas, feel free to drop a comment or reach out through the contact page.
See you in the next post —
Souren
“The first step doesn’t have to be perfect — it just has to be taken.”
title: Welcome to My Blog — A Fresh Beginning
